questions.question_en: Why do cats purr?
questions.question_zh: 猫咪为什么会发出咕噜声？
explanations_en: Wrong. While cats do purr when happy, they also purr when scared, hurt, or giving birth. Purring serves multiple purposes beyond just expressing happiness.

Correct! Cats purr for many reasons: comfort, healing, and self-soothing. The vibrations (25-150 Hz) may help heal bones and reduce pain. Mother cats purr to calm kittens, and injured cats purr to self-soothe. It's a multi-purpose comfort tool!
Wrong. While mother cats do use purring to communicate with kittens, it's not specifically to call them. Cats use different vocalizations like meowing or chirping to call their young.
Wrong. Purring is not caused by breathing through the nose. It's produced by rapid vibration of muscles in the larynx (voice box), causing the vocal cords to vibrate as the cat breathes in and out.
explanations_zh: 错啦！猫咪开心时会咕噜，但害怕、受伤或生产时也会。咕噜声可不只是表达快乐哦，它还有更多用途呢！
对啦！猫咪咕噜有多种原因：舒适、疗愈和自我安抚。振动（25-150赫兹）可能帮助愈合骨骼、减轻疼痛。猫妈妈咕噜安抚小猫，受伤猫咪咕噜自我安慰。它是个多功能的舒适工具！
错啦！猫妈妈确实用咕噜声和小猫交流，但不是专门用来呼唤的。猫咪会用喵叫或啁啾声等不同叫声来呼唤幼崽。
错啦！咕噜声不是用鼻子呼吸引起的。它是由喉部肌肉快速振动产生的，导致声带在猫咪呼吸时振动。

questions.question_en: Why do dogs wag their tails?
questions.question_zh: 狗狗为什么摇尾巴？
explanations_en: Wrong. Tail wagging doesn't always mean happiness. Fast, stiff wagging can indicate aggression or high arousal. A tucked, slow wag might show fear. It's important to read the whole body language.

Correct! Tail wagging shows various emotions. A relaxed, wide wag means friendly. Fast, stiff wagging can mean arousal or aggression. Direction matters: wagging right often shows positive feelings, left shows negative. It's body language we can read to understand their mood!
Wrong. While the tail does help with balance, that's not why dogs wag it. Wagging is primarily for communication of emotions. The balance function is separate from the wagging behavior.
Wrong. Dogs don't wag their tails to keep flies away. That's more common in horses and cows. Dogs wag specifically to communicate emotions and intentions to other animals and humans.
explanations_zh: 错误。摇尾巴不一定代表开心。快速僵硬的摇摆可能表示攻击性或高度兴奋，夹着尾巴慢摇可能显示恐惧。要结合整体肢体语言来判断。
正确！摇尾巴能表达多种情绪。放松的大幅度摇摆表示友好，快速僵硬的摇摆可能意味着兴奋或攻击性。方向也很重要：向右摇常表示积极情绪，向左摇则显示负面情绪。这是我们可以解读的肢体语言，帮助我们了解它们的心情！
错误。虽然尾巴确实有助于平衡，但这并不是狗狗摇尾巴的原因。摇尾巴主要是为了传达情绪。平衡功能与摇尾巴行为是分开的。
错误。狗狗摇尾巴不是为了赶走苍蝇。这更常见于马和牛。狗狗摇尾巴主要是为了向其他动物和人类传达情绪和意图。

questions.question_en: Why do birds migrate?
questions.question_zh: 鸟儿为什么每年都要长途跋涉地迁徙？
choices_zh: 追随季节性的食物来源
explanations_en: Wrong. Temperature is a factor, but not the main reason. Some Arctic birds migrate to Antarctica, still experiencing cold. It's about food availability, not just escaping cold.

Correct! Birds migrate primarily to follow seasonal food sources. In winter, insects and plants become scarce in cold regions. Birds fly to warmer areas with abundant food. Some Arctic birds even migrate to Antarctica, following summer and food! This journey requires enormous energy but ensures survival.

Wrong. Predator avoidance is not the primary driver of migration. Predators exist in both breeding and wintering grounds. The energy cost of migration would be too high if it were just about avoiding predators.

Wrong. While birds do seek good nesting sites, they typically return to the same breeding grounds each year. Migration is driven by seasonal food availability, not the search for better nesting locations.
explanations_zh: 错啦！温度确实是个因素，但不是主要原因。有些北极鸟类会迁徙到南极洲，那里依然很冷。迁徙的关键在于食物可得性，而不仅仅是逃离寒冷。
答对啦！鸟儿迁徙主要是为了追随季节性的食物来源。冬天时，寒冷地区的昆虫和植物变得稀少，鸟儿就飞到食物丰富的温暖地带。有些北极鸟类甚至会飞到南极洲，追逐那里的夏天和食物！这段旅程需要耗费巨大能量，但能确保生存。
错啦！躲避天敌并不是迁徙的主要驱动力。天敌在繁殖地和越冬地都存在。如果只是为了躲避天敌，迁徙的能量成本就太高啦。
错啦！虽然鸟儿确实会寻找好的筑巢地点，但它们通常每年都会回到相同的繁殖地。迁徙是由季节性的食物可得性驱动的，而不是为了寻找更好的筑巢地点。

questions.question_en: Why do cats land on their feet?
questions.question_zh: 为什么猫咪总能四脚着地？
explanations_en: Wrong. Cats don't have special bones for landing. Their skeletal structure is similar to other mammals. It's their flexible spine and inner ear balance system that enables the righting reflex.

Correct! Cats have an extremely flexible spine with extra vertebrae that allows them to twist their body mid-air. Combined with their inner ear balance system, they can rotate their front and back independently. This 'righting reflex' develops around 3-4 weeks old!
Wrong. While the tail helps with balance, tailless cats (like Manx breed) can still land on their feet. The key is the flexible spine and vestibular system in the inner ear.
Wrong. Cats don't sense the ground to land properly. Their righting reflex is triggered by the vestibular apparatus in their inner ear detecting the fall orientation, not ground proximity.
explanations_zh: 错啦！猫咪没有专门用来着陆的特殊骨头，它们的骨骼和其他哺乳动物差不多。真正起作用的是灵活的脊柱和内耳平衡系统，让它们能完成空中翻身。
答对啦！猫咪的脊柱超级灵活，多出的脊椎骨让它们能在空中扭转身体。配合内耳平衡系统，前后半身可以独立转动。这种“翻正反射”在小猫3-4周大时就会啦！
不对哦~虽然尾巴能辅助平衡，但没尾巴的曼岛猫照样能四脚着地。关键还是靠灵活的脊柱和内耳里的前庭系统。
错啦！猫咪不是靠感知地面来调整落地的。它们的翻正反射是由内耳前庭器官感知下落方向触发的，和地面远近没关系。

questions.question_en: Why do dolphins sleep with one eye open?
questions.question_zh: 为什么海豚睡觉时睁着一只眼睛？
explanations_en: Wrong. While watching for danger is a benefit, it's not the reason. The mechanism is unihemispheric slow-wave sleep where half the brain sleeps while the other half stays awake.

Correct! Dolphins use 'unihemispheric sleep' where one brain hemisphere sleeps while the other stays awake. This allows them to breathe consciously (they can't breathe automatically like us), watch for threats, and maintain pod contact. They switch sides every 2 hours!
Wrong. Dolphins do sleep, but differently than land mammals. They need rest but must remain partially conscious to surface and breathe, since breathing is voluntary for them.

Wrong. While continued swimming is necessary and enabled by this sleep pattern, it's not the primary reason. The key is that dolphins must breathe consciously, so part of their brain must always stay awake.
explanations_zh: 错误。虽然警惕危险是好处，但这不是原因。机制是单半球慢波睡眠，一半大脑睡觉时另一半保持清醒。
正确！海豚采用'单半球睡眠'，一个大脑半球睡觉时另一个保持清醒。这能让它们有意识地呼吸（它们不能像我们一样自动呼吸）、警惕威胁并保持群体联系。它们每2小时切换一次！
错误。海豚确实睡觉，但方式与陆地哺乳动物不同。它们需要休息，但必须保持部分意识以浮出水面呼吸，因为呼吸对它们是自主行为。
错误。虽然持续游泳是必要的，且这种睡眠模式使之成为可能，但这不是主要原因。关键在于海豚必须有意识地呼吸，所以部分大脑必须始终保持清醒。

questions.question_en: Why do elephants have good memory?
questions.question_zh: 大象为什么记忆力超群？
choices_zh: 大脑巨大且神经元复杂
explanations_en: Wrong. While elephants do live 60-70 years, longevity alone doesn't create better memory. Many long-lived species don't have exceptional memory. Brain structure and size matter more.

Correct! Elephants have large brains (5kg, largest among land animals) with highly developed hippocampus and cerebral cortex. They can remember herd members, water sources, and migration routes for decades. They even recognize humans they met years ago!
Wrong. Elephants don't write or use external memory aids. Their impressive memory is biological, stored in their large, complex brains.

Wrong. There's no special memory organ. Their exceptional memory comes from their large brain size and particularly well-developed hippocampus, the brain region crucial for forming and storing long-term memories.
explanations_zh: 错啦！虽然大象能活60-70年，但长寿不等于记忆力好。很多长寿动物记忆力并不突出，关键还是大脑结构和大小。
答对啦！大象大脑重达5公斤（陆地动物之最），海马体和大脑皮层特别发达。能记住同伴、水源、迁徙路线几十年，甚至能认出多年前见过的人类！
错啦！大象不会写字也不用外部工具，惊人的记忆力全靠天生的大容量复杂大脑。
错啦！没有特殊记忆器官。超凡记忆力来自硕大的脑容量和高度发达的海马体——这个脑区专管长期记忆的形成和储存。

questions.question_en: Why do fireflies light up at night?
questions.question_zh: 萤火虫为什么在夜晚发光？
explanations_en: Wrong. Fireflies don't use their light to see. Their eyes are adapted to darkness and they navigate using other senses. The bioluminescence is specifically for communication, not illumination.

Correct! Fireflies produce light through bioluminescence using luciferin and luciferase enzymes. Males flash specific patterns to attract females of their species. Each species has unique flash patterns - like a secret code! Females respond with their own flashes. It's nature's light-based dating app!
Wrong. While the light might occasionally startle predators, that's not its primary purpose. The specific, rhythmic patterns are designed for mate attraction, not defense.
Wrong. Fireflies produce their own light through a chemical reaction (bioluminescence), not by storing or reflecting sunlight. The reaction happens in special light organs in their abdomen.
explanations_zh: 错误。萤火虫不是用光来看东西的。它们的眼睛适应黑暗，靠其他感官导航。生物发光是专门用于交流的，不是照明。
正确！萤火虫通过生物发光产生光，利用荧光素和荧光素酶。雄性发出特定闪光模式来吸引同种雌性。每种萤火虫都有独特的闪光模式——就像秘密代码！雌性会用闪光回应。这是大自然的“光速约会”应用！
错误。虽然光偶尔可能吓到捕食者，但这并非主要目的。那些特定、有节奏的模式是为吸引伴侣设计的，不是防御。
错误。萤火虫通过化学反应（生物发光）自己产生光，不是储存或反射阳光。反应发生在它们腹部的特殊发光器官中。

questions.question_en: Why mosquitoes bite some people more?
questions.question_zh: 为什么蚊子总爱叮某些人？
explanations_en: Wrong. Blood doesn't have a 'sweet' taste that mosquitoes can detect from a distance. They find hosts using chemical and thermal cues, not blood sugar levels.

Correct! Mosquitoes are attracted to CO2 from breath, body heat, and specific body odors created by skin bacteria. People with more skin bacteria, higher body temperature, or blood type O get bitten more. Pregnancy increases CO2 output, making pregnant women mosquito magnets. Genetics affect body odor too!
Wrong. While mosquitoes can see colors, this isn't a primary factor. Dark colors might retain more heat (which attracts them), but chemical signals like CO2 and body odor are much more important.

Wrong. Eating sugar doesn't change your blood chemistry enough to attract mosquitoes. However, drinking beer can increase attractiveness slightly, possibly due to increased body temperature and changed skin emissions.
explanations_zh: 错啦！血液可没有‘甜味’能让蚊子老远闻到。蚊子是靠化学信号和体温找目标的，跟血糖高低没关系哦。
对啦！蚊子会被我们呼出的二氧化碳、身体热量，还有皮肤细菌产生的特殊体味吸引。皮肤细菌多、体温高或O型血的人更招蚊子。孕妇呼出更多二氧化碳，简直是蚊子磁铁！遗传也会影响体味呢。
错啦！蚊子虽然能看见颜色，但这可不是主要原因。深色衣服可能更保暖（会吸引蚊子），但二氧化碳和体味这些化学信号才是关键。
错啦！吃糖不会让血液成分大变样去吸引蚊子。不过喝啤酒可能会让你稍微更招蚊子，可能是因为体温升高或皮肤分泌物变化了。

questions.question_en: Why owls turn heads 270 degrees?
questions.question_zh: 猫头鹰为什么能转头270度？
explanations_en: Wrong. While neck muscles play a role, that's not the main reason. Many animals have flexible necks but can't turn their heads this far. The key is that owl eyes are fixed in their sockets.
Wrong. Owls do have 14 neck vertebrae (humans have 7), but the main reason for head rotation is their fixed eyes. The extra vertebrae help enable the rotation, but aren't the primary driver.

Correct! Owl eyes are tubular and completely fixed in their sockets - they cannot move at all! To compensate, they evolved the ability to rotate their heads up to 270 degrees. Special vertebrae, blood vessel adaptations, and flexible neck structures prevent injury during these extreme rotations.

Wrong. While owls have excellent hearing and do turn their heads to locate sounds, the extreme rotation ability exists because their eyes are fixed. Hearing helps them hunt, but doesn't explain the 270-degree rotation.
explanations_zh: 错误。虽然颈部肌肉有作用，但这不是主要原因。许多动物颈部灵活，却无法转头这么远。关键在于猫头鹰的眼睛固定在眼窝里。
错误。猫头鹰确实有14节颈椎（人类只有7节），但头部旋转的主因是它们的固定眼睛。额外颈椎帮助实现旋转，但不是主要驱动力。
正确！猫头鹰的眼睛呈管状，完全固定在眼窝里——根本动不了！为了弥补，它们进化出转头270度的能力。特殊颈椎、血管适应和灵活颈部结构防止了极端旋转时的损伤。
错误。虽然猫头鹰听力极佳，转头确实有助于定位声音，但极端旋转能力的存在是因为眼睛固定。听力帮助捕猎，但无法解释270度旋转。

questions.question_en: Why do penguins huddle together?
questions.question_zh: 企鹅为什么喜欢挤成一团？
explanations_en: Correct! Emperor penguins huddle during Antarctic winters (-40°C winds) to conserve heat. The huddle can have thousands of penguins, with interior temperature reaching 37°C while outside is -20°C! They rotate positions so everyone gets a turn in the warm center. This coordinated behavior is essential for survival!
Wrong. Penguins huddle primarily for warmth, not predator protection. During breeding season on ice, their main threats are aerial predators like skuas, and huddling doesn't protect against them.

Wrong. While huddling does involve social interaction, it's not primarily for bonding. It's a survival mechanism for extreme cold. The behavior is driven by thermoregulation necessity, not social needs.
Wrong. Penguins don't share food within huddles. Adult emperor penguins fast for months during breeding season while incubating eggs. The huddle is purely for thermal protection.
explanations_zh: 正确！帝企鹅在南极冬季（零下40°C的寒风）中挤成一团来保存热量。企鹅群可达数千只，内部温度能升至37°C，而外部只有零下20°C！它们会轮换位置，让每只企鹅都能轮到温暖的中央。这种协调行为对生存至关重要！
错误。企鹅挤团主要是为了保暖，而非躲避捕食者。在冰上繁殖季节，它们的主要威胁是像贼鸥这样的空中捕食者，挤团并不能有效防御它们。
错误。虽然挤团涉及社交互动，但主要目的不是联谊。这是应对极端寒冷的生存机制，行为由体温调节需求驱动，而非社交需求。
错误。企鹅在挤团时不会分享食物。成年帝企鹅在繁殖季节孵蛋时会禁食数月，挤团纯粹是为了保暖。

questions.question_en: Why do snakes shed their skin?
questions.question_zh: 蛇为什么要蜕皮？
explanations_en: Correct! Snake skin doesn't grow with their body, so they must shed (ecdysis) to accommodate growth. Young snakes shed every few weeks, adults several times yearly. Shedding also removes parasites, repairs damage, and refreshes eye scales. The entire outer layer comes off in one piece!

Wrong. While shedding does remove parasites, that's a beneficial side effect, not the main reason. Snakes shed primarily because their skin doesn't stretch as they grow. Even in parasite-free environments, they still shed regularly.
Wrong. Snakes don't change color through shedding. Their color patterns are determined by pigment cells in deeper skin layers that don't shed. The new skin underneath has the same pattern as before.
Wrong. Cleanliness isn't why snakes shed. Their skin doesn't grow, so they must replace it as they grow larger. Shedding is a growth-related process, not a hygiene one.
explanations_zh: 正确！蛇的皮肤不会随身体长大，必须蜕皮（蜕皮过程）来适应生长。幼蛇几周蜕一次，成年蛇一年蜕几次。蜕皮还能清除寄生虫、修复损伤、更新眼鳞。整个外层皮肤会一次性完整脱落！
错误。虽然蜕皮确实能清除寄生虫，但这只是有益副作用，不是主要原因。蛇蜕皮主要是因为皮肤在生长时无法伸展。即使在无寄生虫环境中，它们仍会定期蜕皮。
错误。蛇不会通过蜕皮改变颜色。它们的颜色图案由深层皮肤中的色素细胞决定，这些细胞不随蜕皮脱落。新皮肤下的图案和之前一样。
错误。清洁不是蛇蜕皮的原因。它们的皮肤不生长，所以必须随着体型增大而更换。蜕皮是生长相关过程，不是卫生行为。

questions.question_en: Why do squirrels bury nuts?
questions.question_zh: 为什么小松鼠爱埋坚果？
explanations_en: Wrong. Nut burying (caching) is not play behavior. It's a serious survival strategy. Squirrels spend significant energy on this activity because it's essential for winter survival.

Correct! Squirrels cache nuts for winter using 'scatter hoarding' - burying nuts in multiple locations. They remember thousands of locations using spatial memory and landmarks. They retrieve 70-80% of buried nuts. The forgotten nuts often grow into trees - squirrels are accidental forest planters!

Wrong. While forgotten nuts do become trees, squirrels don't bury nuts with the intention of planting. They're trying to store food for themselves. Forest growth is an unintentional beneficial side effect.

Wrong. Burying nuts is about long-term storage, not immediate hiding. Squirrels often bury nuts in plain sight and rely on memory to find them later. It's a sophisticated food storage system, not a simple hiding behavior.
explanations_zh: 错啦！埋坚果可不是闹着玩的，这是它们重要的生存策略。小松鼠会花大力气做这件事，因为冬天就靠它活命啦！
对啦！小松鼠用‘分散储藏法’把坚果埋在不同地方，它们靠空间记忆和地标记住上千个藏宝点，能找回七八成坚果。那些被忘掉的坚果常常长成大树——小松鼠可是意外的森林园丁呢！
错啦！虽然被忘掉的坚果确实能长成树，但小松鼠埋坚果可不是为了种树，纯粹是想给自己存粮。森林变茂密只是意外的美好副作用哦！
错啦！埋坚果是为了长期储存，不是临时躲藏。小松鼠常把坚果埋在最显眼的地方，靠记忆力后来找。这可是高级的储粮系统，不是简单的藏东西行为。

questions.question_en: Why do zebras have stripes?
questions.question_zh: 斑马为什么长着条纹？
explanations_en: Wrong. Zebras are quite visible in grasslands - their stripes don't blend in. Lions and other predators have no trouble spotting zebras. Research shows stripes don't function as effective camouflage.

Wrong. While the 'motion dazzle' theory was popular, research shows predators aren't confused by stripes during hunts. Lions successfully catch zebras despite the stripes. The confusion hypothesis lacks strong evidence.

Correct! Recent research shows stripes primarily deter biting flies (tsetse and horseflies) which carry diseases. Flies have trouble landing on striped patterns. In experiments, horses wearing striped coats had 70% fewer fly landings! The stripe width matches fly visual sensitivity patterns.
Wrong. While each zebra has unique stripe patterns, individual recognition isn't the primary evolutionary reason for stripes. They use other cues like scent and vocalizations for recognition.
explanations_zh: 错啦！斑马在草原上其实很显眼——它们的条纹根本藏不住。狮子和捕食者一眼就能发现斑马。研究表明，条纹起不到有效的伪装作用。
不对哦！虽然‘动态迷惑’理论曾很流行，但研究发现捕食者在追捕时不会被条纹搞晕。狮子照样能成功抓到斑马，这个假说缺乏有力证据。
答对啦！最新研究显示，条纹主要是为了赶走携带疾病的叮咬苍蝇（如舌蝇和马蝇）。苍蝇很难落在条纹图案上。实验中，披着条纹外套的马被苍蝇叮咬的次数减少了70%！条纹宽度正好匹配苍蝇的视觉敏感模式。
错啦！虽然每匹斑马的条纹都独一无二，但个体识别不是条纹进化的主要原因。它们靠气味和叫声等其他方式认伙伴。

questions.question_en: Why can't penguins fly?
questions.question_zh: 企鹅为什么不会飞？
explanations_en: Wrong. Wing size alone isn't the issue. Penguins have proportionally appropriate wings for their body, but these wings evolved for a different purpose - swimming, not flying.

Correct! Penguins evolved from flying birds but adapted to excel at swimming. Their wings became flippers optimized for underwater 'flight' - reaching speeds of 22 mph! The biomechanics for efficient swimming conflict with aerial flight. Dense bones (unlike hollow bird bones) help them dive deep. Evolution favored swimming specialization!

Wrong. Weight is a factor, but not the primary reason. If penguins had wings designed for flight, their weight could be manageable. The key is that their wings evolved specifically for swimming, making aerial flight biomechanically impossible.

Wrong. This implies random loss, but penguin wing evolution was purposeful adaptation. They didn't 'lose' flight ability - they traded it for superior swimming capabilities through natural selection. It was an evolutionary trade-off, not a loss.
explanations_zh: 错啦！光说翅膀小可不对。企鹅的翅膀和身体比例其实挺合适的，但它们进化成了游泳专用“小桨”，不是用来飞天的。
答对啦！企鹅的祖先本是飞鸟，但为了在水里称霸，翅膀进化成了鳍状肢，游起来嗖嗖的，时速能到35公里！游泳的力学和飞行冲突，加上骨头密实（不像空心的鸟骨）方便深潜，进化就专攻游泳啦！
错啦！体重是因素，但不是主因。如果翅膀为飞行设计，体重本可应付。关键是翅膀专为游泳而生，从生物力学上就飞不起来。
错啦！这说法像随机丢掉的，但企鹅翅膀进化是主动适应。它们没“失去”飞行能力，而是通过自然选择用飞行换了游泳超能力，是进化权衡，不是丢失。

questions.question_en: Why do bees make honey?
questions.question_zh: 蜜蜂为啥要酿造蜂蜜呢？
explanations_en: Wrong. Bees don't make honey for humans. Honey production evolved millions of years before humans started beekeeping. Bees make honey solely for their own colony's survival.

Correct! Bees make honey as their winter food supply. They collect nectar, process it with enzymes, and store it in hexagonal cells. One hive makes 30-60 lbs yearly! Honey never spoils due to low moisture and acidic pH. Worker bees need this energy-dense food when flowers aren't blooming and they can't leave the hive.
Wrong. Bees visit flowers to collect nectar, not to attract them. Flowers are stationary plants - they can't move to a hive. Bees are attracted to flowers, not the other way around.

Wrong. While bees do control hive temperature by fanning their wings, honey isn't used for cooling. Honey is specifically an energy-rich food storage system for survival during winter and periods of scarcity.
explanations_zh: 错啦！蜜蜂可不是为了人类才酿蜜的。早在人类养蜂前几百万年，蜜蜂就演化出酿蜜的本领了，它们纯粹是为了自己族群的生存。
答对啦！蜜蜂酿蜜是为了储备过冬食物。它们采集花蜜，用酶加工后储存在六角形蜂房里。一个蜂巢每年能产30-60斤蜂蜜呢！蜂蜜因水分少、酸性强而永不腐坏，冬天没花采时，工蜂就靠这高能量食物补充体力。
不对哦~蜜蜂是去花朵上采蜜，可不是为了吸引花朵。花朵是固定植物，根本不会动，更不可能跑到蜂巢去。是蜜蜂被花朵吸引，而不是反过来。
错啦！虽然蜜蜂确实会扇动翅膀调节蜂巢温度，但蜂蜜可不是用来降温的。蜂蜜是专门为应对寒冬和食物短缺时期储备的高能量口粮。

questions.question_en: Why do chameleons change color?
questions.question_zh: 变色龙为什么会变色？
explanations_en: Wrong. Chameleons don't perfectly match their surroundings. Their color changes are limited to their species' range (greens, browns, reds). The primary purpose isn't camouflage - many stay visible even after color change.

Correct! Chameleons change color mainly to communicate emotions and intentions. Bright colors signal aggression or courtship, darker colors show submission or stress. They adjust nanocrystal spacing in skin cells to reflect different wavelengths. Temperature regulation is a secondary benefit. It's like mood ring biology!
Wrong. While color can slightly affect heat absorption, that's not why they change color. Temperature regulation through color change is a minor side benefit, not the primary evolutionary purpose.

Wrong. Chameleons are sit-and-wait predators relying on camouflage while stationary and their long, fast tongues for catching prey. Color changes are too slow to confuse insects and aren't used during hunting.
explanations_zh: 错啦！变色龙并不能完美融入环境，它们的变色范围有限（绿、棕、红等），主要目的不是伪装——很多变色后依然显眼。
正确！变色龙变色主要是为了交流情绪和意图：鲜艳颜色表示攻击或求偶，深色显示顺从或压力。它们通过调节皮肤细胞中纳米晶体间距来反射不同波长的光，温度调节只是次要作用，就像生物版情绪戒指！
错啦！颜色虽能轻微影响吸热，但这不是变色原因。通过变色调节温度只是次要附带好处，并非主要进化目的。
错啦！变色龙是伏击型捕食者，靠静止时的伪装和快速长舌捕猎。变色速度太慢，无法迷惑昆虫，捕食时也不会使用。

questions.question_en: Why do woodpeckers peck trees?
questions.question_zh: 啄木鸟为什么总爱啄树？
explanations_en: Wrong. Woodpecker beaks don't need sharpening like tools. They continuously grow to replace wear. Pecking serves specific purposes: finding food, creating nest cavities, and communication - not beak maintenance.

Correct! Woodpeckers peck for multiple reasons: excavating insects (beetles, ants) from tree bark, creating nest cavities in dead wood, and 'drumming' to communicate territory and attract mates. They can peck 20 times per second! Special skull adaptations prevent brain damage from the impact.

Wrong. While drumming does mark territory, that's only one of three main pecking purposes. They also peck to find food and excavate nest holes. Territory marking alone wouldn't explain the extensive pecking behavior.

Wrong. Pecking isn't for exercise. It's a purposeful behavior for survival: finding food in tree bark, creating homes in tree cavities, and communication through rhythmic drumming. The strong muscles evolved to support these functions.
explanations_zh: 错误。啄木鸟的喙不像工具需要磨尖，它们会持续生长以替换磨损。啄树有特定目的：寻找食物、建造巢穴和交流——不是为了保养喙。
正确！啄木鸟啄树有多种原因：从树皮中挖出昆虫（如甲虫、蚂蚁）、在枯木中开凿巢穴，以及通过“敲击”来宣示领地和吸引配偶。它们每秒能啄20次！特殊的头骨结构能防止冲击造成脑损伤。
错误。虽然敲击确实能标记领地，但这只是啄树的三个主要目的之一。它们还啄树来寻找食物和挖掘巢洞。仅靠标记领地无法解释广泛的啄树行为。
错误。啄树不是为了锻炼。这是一种为了生存的有目的行为：在树皮中寻找食物、在树洞中安家，以及通过有节奏的敲击进行交流。强壮的肌肉进化而来是为了支持这些功能。

questions.question_en: Why do dogs have wet noses?
questions.question_zh: 为什么狗狗的鼻子总是湿漉漉的？
explanations_en: Wrong. While dogs do lick their noses, that's not why noses are wet. Special mucous glands in the nose produce moisture that helps trap scent particles. Licking helps clean the nose and transfer scents to the mouth for analysis.

Correct! Dogs' noses have mucous glands that keep them moist. The moisture layer helps absorb and trap scent chemicals, dramatically improving their already powerful sense of smell. It also aids evaporative cooling. Dogs lick their noses to sample scents and keep the nose clean and functional!

Wrong. While a wet nose often indicates health, wetness itself isn't just a health indicator. The moisture serves functional purposes: enhancing scent detection and temperature regulation. A temporarily dry nose doesn't always mean illness.

Wrong. Dog noses don't collect atmospheric water. The moisture comes from specialized mucus-producing glands inside the nose. The wetness serves to enhance olfactory ability and cooling, not hydration.
explanations_zh: 错误。虽然狗狗确实会舔鼻子，但这并非鼻子湿润的原因。鼻子里的特殊黏液腺会分泌水分，帮助捕捉气味颗粒。舔鼻子有助于清洁鼻子，并将气味传递到嘴里进行分析。
正确！狗狗的鼻子有黏液腺，能保持湿润。这层水分有助于吸收和捕捉气味化学物质，显著增强它们本就强大的嗅觉。同时还能帮助蒸发降温。狗狗舔鼻子是为了采样气味，并保持鼻子清洁和功能正常！
错误。虽然湿润的鼻子通常表示健康，但湿润本身不仅仅是健康指标。这种水分具有功能性：增强气味检测和温度调节。暂时干燥的鼻子并不总是意味着生病。
错误。狗狗的鼻子不会从大气中收集水分。湿润来自鼻子内部专门产生黏液的腺体。这种湿润是为了增强嗅觉能力和降温，而不是为了补充水分。

questions.question_en: Why do cats' eyes glow in the dark?
questions.question_zh: 为什么猫的眼睛在黑暗中会发光？
choices_zh: 反光膜将光线反射回来
explanations_en: Wrong. Cats don't produce light like fireflies. Their eyes glow because they reflect available light, not generate it. Without any light source, cat eyes appear dark.

Correct! Cats have a reflective layer called tapetum lucidum behind their retinas. It reflects light back through the retina, giving photoreceptors a second chance to detect it. This boosts night vision by up to 6 times! The 'glow' is reflected light, not produced light. Eye color affects glow color!

Wrong. Eyes don't absorb and store light like solar panels. The glow is immediate reflection of available light (any light source, not just moon). When light hits the tapetum lucidum, it bounces back instantly, creating the glow effect.

Wrong. Cats don't have bioluminescent proteins. The glow is purely optical - light reflecting off the tapetum lucidum structure. It's a physical reflection phenomenon, not a biological light production.
explanations_zh: 错啦！猫不像萤火虫那样自己发光。它们的眼睛发光是因为反射了周围的光线，而不是自己产生光。如果没有光源，猫的眼睛看起来就是暗的。
正确！猫的视网膜后面有一层叫做反光膜的结构。它把光线反射回视网膜，让感光细胞有第二次机会捕捉光线，这能让夜视能力提升高达6倍！这种'发光'是反射光，不是自发光。眼睛颜色还会影响发光的颜色哦！
错啦！眼睛不会像太阳能板那样吸收和储存光线。发光是光线立即反射的结果（任何光源，不只是月光）。当光线打到反光膜上时，它会瞬间反弹回来，形成发光效果。
错啦！猫没有生物发光蛋白质。这种发光纯粹是光学现象——光线从反光膜结构上反射回来。这是一种物理反射现象，不是生物发光。

questions.question_en: Why do horses sleep standing up?
questions.question_zh: 马儿为什么站着睡觉？
explanations_en: Wrong. Horses can and do lie down - they need to for REM sleep. Weight isn't the issue. They have a special 'stay apparatus' in their legs that locks joints, allowing them to doze standing without muscle effort.

Correct! Horses evolved as prey animals on open plains. Standing sleep allows instant flight from predators. A special leg-locking mechanism (stay apparatus) lets them doze standing without tiring. However, they MUST lie down for deep REM sleep (2-3 hours daily) or they become sleep-deprived. It's a survival balance!

Wrong. Lying down doesn't harm healthy horses. They regularly lie down for deep REM sleep. Large horses can develop circulation issues if lying on one side too long, but this isn't why they stand to sleep - predator escape is the evolutionary driver.

Wrong. Getting up doesn't require excessive energy for healthy horses. The standing sleep ability evolved specifically for predator escape, not energy conservation. The 'stay apparatus' saves energy while standing, but that's a mechanism enabling the behavior, not the reason for it.
explanations_zh: 错啦！马儿其实会躺下睡觉，它们需要躺着才能进入深度REM睡眠。体重不是问题，它们腿里有特殊的‘锁定装置’，能让关节固定，站着打盹不费劲。
对啦！马儿在开阔草原上演化成猎物，站着睡觉能瞬间逃跑。腿部的‘锁定装置’让它们站着打盹不累，但每天必须躺下2-3小时进行深度REM睡眠，否则会睡眠不足。这是生存的平衡！
错啦！躺着不会伤害健康的马儿，它们经常躺下深度睡眠。大型马如果长时间侧躺可能血液循环不畅，但这和站着睡觉无关——进化是为了躲避捕食者。
错啦！健康的马儿站起来不费多少力气。站着睡觉的能力是专门为躲避捕食者演化的，不是为了省力。‘锁定装置’在站立时省力，但那是实现行为的方式，不是原因。

questions.question_en: Why do bats hang upside down?
questions.question_zh: 蝙蝠为什么喜欢倒挂着睡觉？
choices_zh: 倒挂能轻松起飞，直接坠落就飞走
倒挂让血液更顺畅地流向大脑
倒挂能躲避天敌的袭击
倒挂只是它们偏爱的睡姿
explanations_en: Correct! Bats have weak legs and can't launch from the ground. Hanging lets them drop into flight instantly. Their tendons lock automatically when gripping, so hanging takes no energy—they can sleep without falling!
Wrong. Bat circulation works fine in any position. Hanging is about flight mechanics, not blood flow.
Wrong. Many predators can climb to where bats roost. Hanging is primarily for flight launch efficiency.
Wrong. Hanging isn't mere preference—it's necessary. Bat leg structure makes ground takeoff nearly impossible.
explanations_zh: 没错！蝙蝠腿部力量弱，无法从地面起飞。倒挂能让它们瞬间坠落起飞，肌腱会自动锁定抓握，倒挂不费劲，睡觉也不会掉下来！
错啦。蝙蝠的血液循环在任何姿势下都正常，倒挂主要是为了飞行启动方便，和血液流动没关系。
错啦。很多天敌都能爬到蝙蝠栖息的地方，倒挂主要是为了起飞更高效，不是为了躲天敌。
错啦。倒挂不是单纯的偏好，而是必须的。蝙蝠的腿部结构让它们几乎不可能从地面起飞。

questions.question_en: Why do camels have humps?
questions.question_zh: 骆驼为什么长着驼峰？
choices_zh: 为了在沙漠中储存水分
为了储存脂肪提供能量
explanations_en: Wrong. This is a common myth! Camels don't store water in humps. Water is distributed throughout their bodies.

Correct! Humps store fat, not water. Camels metabolize this fat for energy and water when food is scarce. A healthy hump is firm; a droopy one means the camel needs food. They can lose 30% of their water and survive!
Wrong. Loads are placed around humps, not balanced by them. Humps exist for fat storage.
Wrong. Heat regulation happens through other adaptations. Humps are specifically fat reserves.
explanations_zh: 错啦！这是个常见误解！骆驼的驼峰不储水，水分分布全身哦。
答对啦！驼峰储存脂肪而非水。骆驼在食物匮乏时分解脂肪获取能量和水。健康驼峰饱满，下垂说明饿了。它们能失水30%还活着！
不对哦。重物放在驼峰周围，不是靠它平衡。驼峰专为储脂而生。
错啦。体温调节靠其他适应机制。驼峰是专门的脂肪储备库。

questions.question_en: Why do sloths move so slowly?
questions.question_zh: 为什么树懒动作这么慢？
explanations_en: Wrong. Sloths aren't tired—slowness is their survival strategy, not exhaustion.
Wrong. Sloth muscles are actually quite weak. Their slowness isn't about strength.

Correct! Sloths eat low-calorie leaves and have very slow metabolisms. Moving slowly conserves energy. It also helps them avoid predators—their slowness makes them hard to spot! They can take a month to digest one meal.
Wrong. Trees aren't particularly slippery. Sloths have curved claws perfect for gripping branches.
explanations_zh: 错。树懒不累——慢是生存策略，不是疲劳。
错。树懒肌肉其实很弱，慢与力量无关。
正确！树懒吃低热量叶子，代谢极慢。慢动作节省能量，还帮它们躲避捕食者——慢让它们难被发现！它们消化一顿饭要一个月。
错。树木不特别滑，树懒有弯爪完美抓握树枝。

questions.question_en: Why do kangaroos hop instead of walk?
questions.question_zh: 袋鼠为什么蹦蹦跳跳，而不是走路呢？
choices_zh: 育儿袋里的宝宝需要颠簸
explanations_en: Correct! At high speeds, hopping uses less energy than running. Kangaroo tendons store and release energy like springs. They can cruise at 25 mph and barely get tired! At slow speeds, they use their tail as a fifth leg.
Wrong. Kangaroos can move their legs independently—they swim by kicking! But on land, hopping is more efficient.
Wrong. Speed is a benefit, but efficiency is the main reason. Hopping uses their spring-like tendons.
Wrong. Joeys aren't why kangaroos hop. The pouch is adapted for hopping, not the other way around.
explanations_zh: 正确！高速蹦跳比奔跑更节能。袋鼠的肌腱像弹簧一样储存和释放能量，能以40公里时速轻松巡航还不累！慢速时，它们会用尾巴当第五条腿。
错误。袋鼠的腿能独立活动——它们游泳时会蹬腿！但在陆地上，蹦跳更高效。
错误。速度是好处，但省力才是主因。蹦跳利用了它们弹簧般的肌腱。
错误。幼崽不是袋鼠蹦跳的原因。育儿袋是为蹦跳演化的，而不是反过来。

questions.question_en: Why do porcupines have quills?
questions.question_zh: 为什么豪猪身上长满了尖刺？
explanations_en: Wrong. Porcupines are herbivores and don't use quills to catch food. They eat plants and bark.

Correct! Quills are modified hairs with barbed tips. When threatened, porcupines raise their quills. If a predator attacks, quills detach and embed painfully. They can't shoot quills—that's a myth—but quills release easily on contact!
Wrong. Quills aren't for mating displays. They're purely defensive.
Wrong. Quills don't function as sensors. Regular hairs and whiskers serve that purpose.
explanations_zh: 错啦！豪猪是食草动物，不吃肉，它们靠植物和树皮填饱肚子。
对啦！这些尖刺其实是特化的毛发，带倒钩。遇到危险时，豪猪竖起尖刺；捕食者一碰，尖刺就脱落并扎进去，疼得它们嗷嗷叫！不过，豪猪可不会发射尖刺哦，那是传说。
错啦！尖刺可不是用来求偶的，它们纯粹是防御武器。
错啦！尖刺没有感知功能，豪猪靠普通毛发和胡须来探测周围。

questions.question_en: Why do frogs croak at night?
questions.question_zh: 为什么青蛙总在夜晚呱呱叫？
choices_zh: 夜晚空气让叫声更响亮
explanations_en: Wrong. Croaking isn't related to hunger. Frogs call for reproductive reasons.
Wrong. Croaking would attract predators, not scare them. Many predators hunt frogs by sound.

Correct! Male frogs croak to attract females during breeding season. Each species has a unique call so females find the right mates. Nighttime is safer for calling when many visual predators are inactive!
Wrong. Night air doesn't affect frog voices. They call at night because it's safer from daytime predators.
explanations_zh: 错！呱呱叫和饥饿无关，青蛙鸣叫是为了繁殖。
错！呱呱叫反而会引来捕食者，许多捕食者靠声音捕食青蛙。
正确！雄蛙在繁殖季节呱呱叫来吸引雌蛙，每种青蛙都有独特叫声，方便雌蛙找到合适伴侣。夜晚更安全，因为许多视觉捕食者不活跃！
错！夜晚空气不影响青蛙叫声，它们在夜晚叫是因为能避开白天捕食者。

questions.question_en: Why do wolves howl?
questions.question_zh: 狼群为什么爱嚎叫？
explanations_en: Correct! Wolves howl to communicate with their pack over miles. Howls can coordinate hunts, announce territory, locate separated members, or strengthen social bonds. Each wolf has a unique voice pack members recognize!
Wrong. Scaring prey would be counterproductive for hunting. Howling is about pack communication.
Wrong. Howling has no digestive function. It's purely for communication.
Wrong. The moon association is a myth. Wolves howl with heads up to project sound farther, often when moon is visible.
explanations_zh: 正确！狼嚎叫是为了与几公里外的同伴沟通。嚎声能协调捕猎、宣示领地、寻找失散成员或加强群体感情。每只狼都有独特声音，同伴一听就认得出！
错啦。吓跑猎物反而会干扰捕猎。嚎叫的核心作用是群体交流。
错啦。嚎叫和消化功能毫无关系，纯粹用于沟通。
错啦。狼对月嚎叫是传说误解。它们抬头嚎叫是为了让声音传更远，月亮常出现时嚎叫更频繁而已。

questions.question_en: Why do animals hibernate in winter?
questions.question_zh: 动物们为什么要在冬天冬眠呢？
explanations_en: Wrong. Many animals are active in cold weather. Hibernation is about food availability, not temperature alone.
Correct! Hibernation lets animals survive when food is scarce. They drastically slow metabolism—some heartbeats drop from 200 to 5 per minute! Body fat provides energy until spring brings food again.
Wrong. Day length triggers hibernation hormones, but the survival advantage is conserving energy when food is unavailable.
Wrong. Snow doesn't trap hibernators. Many dig dens or find sheltered spots before hibernating.
explanations_zh: 错啦！很多动物在寒冷天气里依然活跃。冬眠的关键是食物短缺，不只是因为温度低。
答对啦！冬眠让动物在食物匮乏时存活下来。它们大幅减缓新陈代谢——有些心跳从每分钟200次降到5次！身体脂肪提供能量，直到春天食物回归。
不对哦。白昼长短会触发冬眠激素，但生存优势在于食物短缺时节省能量。
错啦！雪不会困住冬眠动物。许多动物在冬眠前会挖洞或找隐蔽处安家。
